articles.headline: As Netanyahu Fails to Form a Government, Benny Gantz Gets a Chance to Try
articles.snippet: The former army chief will have 28 days to assemble a coalition government for the fiercely divided country. Otherwise, a third election could follow.
articles.abstract: The former army chief will have 28 days to assemble a coalition government for the fiercely divided country. Otherwise, a third election could follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel abandoned his latest attempt to form a government on Monday, clearing the way for his chief rival to take a shot but leaving a divided country no closer to knowing who its next leader would be.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Facebook Lays On the Charm for Its Libra Cryptocurrency Plan
articles.snippet: Executives fanned out in Washington to court lawmakers and regulators. Mark Zuckerberg is expected to testify about Libra this week before the House.
articles.abstract: Executives fanned out in Washington to court lawmakers and regulators. Mark Zuckerberg is expected to testify about Libra this week before the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facebook’s ambitious plan to create a cryptocurrency that would replace traditional money all over the world appears to be on life support. Regulators and lawmakers have mocked it. Key partners like Visa and Mastercard have stepped away from it.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Boeing’s Crisis Grows: Tense Meetings, Falling Stock, Angry Lawmakers
articles.snippet: The crash of two 737 Max jets has thrown the company into the biggest crisis in its 103-year history, and things seem to be getting worse.
articles.abstract: The crash of two 737 Max jets has thrown the company into the biggest crisis in its 103-year history, and things seem to be getting worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Boeing’s board gathered on Monday, it confronted a grim reality. The crash of two 737 Max jets had already thrown the company into the biggest crisis in its 103-year history, and things only seemed to be getting worse.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: For Trump the Dealmaker, Troop Pullouts Without Much in Return
articles.snippet: The president has sought to scale back America’s military presence around the world without waiting to negotiate concessions from foes like the Taliban or North Korea.
articles.abstract: The president has sought to scale back America’s military presence around the world without waiting to negotiate concessions from foes like the Taliban or North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Taliban have wanted the United States to pull troops out of Afghanistan, Turkey has wanted the Americans out of northern Syria and North Korea has wanted them to at least stop military exercises with South Korea.

articles.headline: Hungary’s Orban Gave Trump Harsh Analysis of Ukraine Before Key Meeting
articles.snippet: The discussion at the White House between President Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban was held over objections from Mr. Trump’s national security adviser.
articles.abstract: The discussion at the White House between President Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban was held over objections from Mr. Trump’s national security adviser.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just 10 days before a key meeting on Ukraine, President Trump met, over the objections of his national security adviser, with one of the former Soviet republic’s most virulent critics, Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, and heard a sharp assessment that bolstered his hostility toward the country, according to several people informed about the situation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: China Sharpens Hacking to Hound Its Minorities, Far and Wide
articles.snippet: New, more sophisticated attacks are targeting Uighurs’ phones — even iPhones and even abroad, security researchers say. They warn that foreigners could be next.
articles.abstract: New, more sophisticated attacks are targeting Uighurs’ phones — even iPhones and even abroad, security researchers say. They warn that foreigners could be next.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — China’s state-sponsored hackers have drastically changed how they operate over the last three years, substituting selectivity for what had been a scattershot approach to their targets and showing a new determination by Beijing to push its surveillance state beyond its borders.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth, Kate Conger and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Putin and Erdogan Announce Plan for Northeast Syria, Bolstering Russian Influence
articles.snippet: Russia’s leader hosted his Turkish counterpart as a U.S.-brokered cease-fire with Kurdish forces came to an end, underscoring Moscow’s emergence as a powerful player in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Russia’s leader hosted his Turkish counterpart as a U.S.-brokered cease-fire with Kurdish forces came to an end, underscoring Moscow’s emergence as a powerful player in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — His jets patrol Syrian skies. His military is expanding operations at the main naval base in Syria. He is forging closer ties to Turkey. He and his Syrian allies are moving into territory vacated by the United States.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: WeWork’s Multibillion-Dollar Takeover by SoftBank Could Turn Into a Money Pit
articles.snippet: The shared-office company, which scrapped an initial public offering and pushed out its chief executive last month, isn’t profitable and may not be for the foreseeable future.
articles.abstract: The shared-office company, which scrapped an initial public offering and pushed out its chief executive last month, isn’t profitable and may not be for the foreseeable future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WeWork said it was going to transform the market for office space, reinvent the way people work and elevate the world’s consciousness. But in recent weeks, the brutal reality beneath the lofty visions has emerged.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis, Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Would You Like Fries With That? McDonald’s Already Knows the Answer
articles.snippet: The fast-food chain is turning to artificial intelligence and machine learning in the hopes of predicting what customers want before they decide.
articles.abstract: The fast-food chain is turning to artificial intelligence and machine learning in the hopes of predicting what customers want before they decide.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.
